articles.headline: Hundreds of Bodies, One Nurse: German Serial Killer Leaves as Many Questions as Victims
articles.snippet: A nurse, Niels Högel, admitted to dozens of murders but might have killed as many as 300 patients. So what prevented colleagues from stopping one of the world’s deadliest serial killers?
articles.abstract: A nurse, Niels Högel, admitted to dozens of murders but might have killed as many as 300 patients. So what prevented colleagues from stopping one of the world’s deadliest serial killers?
articles.lead_paragraph: OLDENBURG, Germany — The new nurse arrived at the intensive-care unit of Delmenhorst hospital with a solid letter of reference, describing him as someone who worked “independently and conscientiously.” In a crisis, it said, he reacted “with consideration” and was “technically correct.”

articles.headline: White House Asked McGahn to Declare Trump Never Obstructed Justice
articles.snippet: Two requests by presidential advisers show how far the White House has gone to try to push back on accusations that the president obstructed justice.
articles.abstract: Two requests by presidential advisers show how far the White House has gone to try to push back on accusations that the president obstructed justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials asked at least twice in the past month for the key witness against President Trump in the Mueller report, Donald F. McGahn II, to say publicly that he never believed the president obstructed justice, according to two people briefed on the requests.

articles.headline: Trump Sees a China Trade Deal Through a New Prism: The 2020 Election
articles.snippet: The president’s recent statements suggest he now believes that demonstrating his toughness with China and walking away from a deal might well put him in a better position politically than signing one.
articles.abstract: The president’s recent statements suggest he now believes that demonstrating his toughness with China and walking away from a deal might well put him in a better position politically than signing one.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump had finished mocking the field of Democratic presidential candidates at a rally in Florida this week (“Sleepy Joe,” “Crazy Bernie” and “Boot-edge-edge”), he pivoted abruptly to his intensifying trade war with China. The segue was no accident: Mr. Trump is determined to present himself as tougher on the Chinese than any of his potential challengers in 2020.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Why Rewards for Loyal Spenders Are ‘a Honey Pot for Hackers’
articles.snippet: Companies are seeking more personal data from faithful customers in exchange for points, miles and other perks. But protections for loyalty accounts have not kept pace.
articles.abstract: Companies are seeking more personal data from faithful customers in exchange for points, miles and other perks. But protections for loyalty accounts have not kept pace.
articles.lead_paragraph: The punch cards stuffed in your wallet know next to nothing about you, except maybe how many frozen yogurts you still need to buy to get a free one.

articles.headline: Inside Syria’s Secret Torture Prisons: How Bashar al-Assad Crushed Dissent
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians have been locked away in filthy prisons where thousands were tortured to death — and the pace of arrests and executions is accelerating.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians have been locked away in filthy prisons where thousands were tortured to death — and the pace of arrests and executions is accelerating.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — Syrian security officers hung Muhannad Ghabbash from his wrists for hours, beat him bloody, shocked him with electricity and stuck a gun in his mouth.

articles.headline: Trump Has a Strong Economy to Proclaim. In Wisconsin, It Just Might Work.
articles.snippet: With good job creation and low unemployment, the president may have a winning message — if he can stay on it — in crucial swing counties near the Mississippi River.
articles.abstract: With good job creation and low unemployment, the president may have a winning message — if he can stay on it — in crucial swing counties near the Mississippi River.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLFAX, Wis. — President Trump came to Wisconsin late last month to boast about the state’s unemployment rate, which has been at or near 3 percent for more than a year. “It’s never been this low before. Ever, ever, ever,” he said. (Fact check: true.)

articles.headline: Trump Said He Would Tame Rogue Nations. Now They Are Challenging Him.
articles.snippet: President Trump said Barack Obama was a patsy who had allowed North Korea, Iran and Venezuela to run roughshod over him. But those nations are pushing back against Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: President Trump said Barack Obama was a patsy who had allowed North Korea, Iran and Venezuela to run roughshod over him. But those nations are pushing back against Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three nations that have long defined themselves as bitter adversaries of the United States — North Korea, Iran and Venezuela — decided this week they could take on President Trump.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Edward Wong

articles.headline: U.S.-China Trade Standoff May Be Initial Skirmish in Broader Economic War
articles.snippet: The United States is wary of China’s growing role in the global economy and its tactics for getting ahead. China sees some of the demands as infringing on its sovereignty.
articles.abstract: The United States is wary of China’s growing role in the global economy and its tactics for getting ahead. China sees some of the demands as infringing on its sovereignty.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A yearlong trade war between the United States and China is proving to be an initial skirmish in an economic conflict that may persist for decades, as both countries battle for global dominance, stature and wealth.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Russia Is Targeting Europe’s Elections. So Are Far-Right Copycats.
articles.snippet: Digital fingerprints link pro-Russian and anti-European websites, part of an online ecosystem that is sowing discord ahead of European elections this month.
articles.abstract: Digital fingerprints link pro-Russian and anti-European websites, part of an online ecosystem that is sowing discord ahead of European elections this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Less than two weeks before pivotal elections for the European Parliament, a constellation of websites and social media accounts linked to Russia or far-right groups is spreading disinformation, encouraging discord and amplifying distrust in the centrist parties that have governed for decades.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: They Were Promised Coding Jobs in Appalachia. Now They Say It Was a Fraud.
articles.snippet: Mined Minds came into West Virginia espousing a certain dogma, fostered in the world of start-ups and TED Talks. Students found an erratic operation.
articles.abstract: Mined Minds came into West Virginia espousing a certain dogma, fostered in the world of start-ups and TED Talks. Students found an erratic operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BECKLEY, W.Va. — On a spring day in 2017, Stephanie Frame sat down in her hilltop home deep in the mountain hollows to record a video.

articles.headline: New Zealand Seeks Global Support for Tougher Measures on Online Violence
articles.snippet: In the wake of the terrorist attack on Muslim mosques, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is calling for a united effort against the biggest internet companies.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the terrorist attack on Muslim mosques, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is calling for a united effort against the biggest internet companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand will attempt this week to use the terrorist attack that killed 51 Muslim worshipers in Christchurch mosques in March to demand that the biggest internet platforms do more to stamp out violent and extremist content.
articles.byline: By Charlotte Graham-McLay and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: Kavanaugh and Gorsuch, Justices With Much in Common, Take Different Paths
articles.snippet: Justices Gorsuch and Kavanaugh were expected to a be jurisprudential twins. In both style and substance, they have embraced different approaches.
articles.abstract: Justices Gorsuch and Kavanaugh were expected to a be jurisprudential twins. In both style and substance, they have embraced different approaches.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s two Supreme Court appointees went to the same Jesuit high school in the Washington suburbs — at the same time. After attending Ivy League colleges and law schools, they worked as law clerks on the Supreme Court — for the same justice, in the same term.

articles.headline: As TV Industry’s $20 Billion Week Starts, Signs That Streaming Isn’t King Yet
articles.snippet: The so-called upfronts are traditional television’s annual hype-fest, and a way of locking advertisers into lucrative deals. They’re also a reminder of the medium’s continuing relevance.
articles.abstract: The so-called upfronts are traditional television’s annual hype-fest, and a way of locking advertisers into lucrative deals. They’re also a reminder of the medium’s continuing relevance.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, the television industry will put on its biggest show of the year, the upfront presentations, an annual deal-making ritual that goes back more than five decades. It has become more important than ever.

articles.headline: How a Newspaper War in New Orleans Ended: With a Baked Alaska and Layoffs
articles.snippet: The Advocate went into New Orleans six years ago to challenge the city’s 182-year-old paper, The Times-Picayune. Now The Advocate is the last one standing.
articles.abstract: The Advocate went into New Orleans six years ago to challenge the city’s 182-year-old paper, The Times-Picayune. Now The Advocate is the last one standing.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The announcement came via the baked alaska.

articles.headline: New Executive of Slimmed-Down Fox Network Faces First Big Test
articles.snippet: Disney’s acquisition of much of Rupert Murdoch’s empire leaves the network vulnerable. Charlie Collier says he, and the network, are up for the challenge.
articles.abstract: Disney’s acquisition of much of Rupert Murdoch’s empire leaves the network vulnerable. Charlie Collier says he, and the network, are up for the challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: The television executive Charlie Collier was a decade into his run as president of the cable channel AMC, where he was instrumental in the success of “The Walking Dead” and “Breaking Bad,” when he got a call last summer from Rupert Murdoch.

articles.headline: U.S.-China Trade Talks Stumble on Beijing’s Spending at Home
articles.snippet: As the trade war intensifies, Chinese subsidies for homegrown industries present a difficult obstacle to reaching a deal.
articles.abstract: As the trade war intensifies, Chinese subsidies for homegrown industries present a difficult obstacle to reaching a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — One year ago, when he began a multibillion-dollar trade war with China that shook the global economy, President Trump demanded that Beijing end lavish government spending aimed at making the country a world power in computer chips, robotics, commercial aircraft and other industries of the future.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Trump’s Trade War Escalation Will Exact Economic Pain, Adviser Says
articles.snippet: President Trump’s decision to renew his trade war with China could inflict lasting damage on the American economy, but the ultimate impact depends on how far the president takes the fight.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s decision to renew his trade war with China could inflict lasting damage on the American economy, but the ultimate impact depends on how far the president takes the fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s chief economic adviser said on Sunday that American consumers would bear some pain from the escalating trade war with China, contradicting Mr. Trump’s claim that his tariffs are a multibillion-dollar, mostly one-way payment by China to the American Treasury.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Jim Tankersley and Mark Landler

articles.headline: An Unending Trade War Leaves Wall Street Jittery
articles.snippet: The economic conflict between the United States and China, the world’s two biggest economies, showed little sign of ending soon.
articles.abstract: The economic conflict between the United States and China, the world’s two biggest economies, showed little sign of ending soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors are dealing with a painful new reality: The trade war between the United States and China could last indefinitely.

articles.headline: ‘This Is All We Can Afford’: Shrinking Lives in the English Countryside
articles.snippet: In Cumbria, a bucolic landscape masks growing poverty and isolation. As bus lines are cut and services dry up under austerity, older people are feeling new constraints.
articles.abstract: In Cumbria, a bucolic landscape masks growing poverty and isolation. As bus lines are cut and services dry up under austerity, older people are feeling new constraints.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALSTON, England — It was not until Trevor Robinson received a letter notifying him of a missed appointment at the hospital that he realized he had not spoken to another human being in more than six weeks.
articles.byline: By Ceylan Yeginsu and Laetitia Vancon

articles.headline: Trade Dispute Between U.S. and China Deepens as Beijing Retaliates
articles.snippet: The escalation rattled markets and thrust the world’s two largest economies, which had seemed on the brink of resolving their differences, back into confrontation.
articles.abstract: The escalation rattled markets and thrust the world’s two largest economies, which had seemed on the brink of resolving their differences, back into confrontation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and China intensified their trade dispute on Monday, as Beijing said it would increase tariffs on nearly $60 billion worth of American goods and the Trump administration detailed plans to tax nearly every sneaker, computer, dress and handbag that China exports to the United States.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Supreme Court Allows Antitrust Lawsuit Against Apple to Proceed
articles.snippet: Plaintiffs argued that the technology giant had used its monopoly power to raise the prices of iPhone apps.
articles.abstract: Plaintiffs argued that the technology giant had used its monopoly power to raise the prices of iPhone apps.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday allowed an enormous antitrust class action against Apple to move forward, saying consumers should be allowed to try to prove that the technology giant had used monopoly power to raise the prices of iPhone apps.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Jack Nicas
